word.entryDescription: a company that carries passengers and goods by aircraft
word.entryExample: What are the disadvantages of flying budget airlines?

word.entryDescription: a place where you go to take a plane
word.entryExample: What time do you want me to meet you at the airport?

word.entryDescription: a device that transmits a warning of danger, especially by making a loud noise
word.entryExample: We were playing outside, so I didn't hear the alarm.

word.entryDescription: a clock that makes a loud sound in order to wake you up
word.entryExample: Tanya didn't have to get up when the alarm clock rang because it was her day off.

word.entryDescription: a collection of several songs, pieces of music, etc released on one CD, etc
word.entryExample: The iconic photo of the Beatles crossing the road outside the studio was used on the cover of one of their most famous albums.

word.entryDescription: something that proves that somebody was somewhere else and therefore could not have committed a crime
word.entryExample: He wasn't arrested because he had an alibi.

word.entryDescription: a creature from another planet
word.entryExample: Are aliens green?

word.entryDescription: the whole number or amount
word.entryExample: Where did they all go?

word.entryDescription: the whole day
word.entryExample: My cat likes to sleep all day.

word.entryDescription: very quickly and unexpectedly
word.entryExample: All of a sudden, he started to run back home.

word.entryDescription: not a problem
word.entryExample: That's all right, you can read my book.

word.entryDescription: a negative condition caused by touching or eating something that might not affect other people
word.entryExample: A possible symptom of a strawberry allergy is a swelling of the tongue.

word.entryDescription: to make it possible for something to happen
word.entryExample: Many countries don't allow people to keep exotic animals as pets.

word.entryDescription: in addition
word.entryExample: I have a sister and I also have a brother.

word.entryDescription: every other or second one of a series
word.entryExample: Cars can only go into the centre of Athens on alternate days, depending on whether their number plates end in an odd or even number.

word.entryDescription: used to link two contrasting clauses together
word.entryExample: Although learning another language isn't easy, it is well worth all the dedication.

word.entryDescription: a silvery white metal that is light in weight and which is used to make cans, foil, vehicle parts, etc
word.entryExample: Most soft drink cans are made of aluminium and can be recycled.

word.entryDescription: all the time
word.entryExample: I always drink tea for breakfast.

word.entryDescription: very surprised, astonished
word.entryExample: The coach was amazed at how good the goalkeeper was.

word.entryDescription: very good or something you don't expect
word.entryExample: What an amazing song!

word.entryDescription: a strong desire to have or achieve something in the future
word.entryExample: Steve's ambition is to build a rocket that can take several people into space.

word.entryDescription: feeling a strong desire to have or achieve something in the future
word.entryExample: Sarah and Jake are both ambitious.

word.entryDescription: a special vehicle used to take sick or injured people to hospital
word.entryExample: You need an ambulance!

word.entryDescription: the name we usually give to the country of the United States of America
word.entryExample: Megan comes from America.

word.entryDescription: of or from the US; of or from America
word.entryExample: In 1973, John Lennon was sued by American rock and roll musician Chuck Berry.

word.entryDescription: friendly and likable
word.entryExample: He is amiable and welcomes everyone with a cheerful smile.

word.entryDescription: thinking that someone or something is funny and making you smile or laugh
word.entryExample: I am not amused. That email isn't funny.

word.entryDescription: a large park with a lot of things you can ride and play on and with various activities to enjoy
word.entryExample: The Euro Luna Park is a huge amusement park.
We get so much enjoyment chatting to each other and sharing amusing videos on the internet.

word.entryDescription: very old, or of a very long time ago
word.entryExample: I wonder what life was like in ancient Egypt.

word.entryDescription: having strong negative feeling because something has upset you
word.entryExample: Don't talk to him now, he's angry.

word.entryDescription: a living thing like a bird, cat or dog
word.entryExample: What's your favourite animal?

word.entryDescription: a type of film or TV programme made by drawing or photographing a series of images or models
word.entryExample: Cartoons and animation are quite similar, but cartoons are always drawings and can be in books or magazines.

word.entryDescription: the part of the body where your foot joins your leg
word.entryExample: Jenny is the nurse who gave Dad treatment for his sprained ankle.

word.entryDescription: to give information, especially about a plan or decision, to others
word.entryExample: The pilot announced that we would be diverting to another airport.

word.entryDescription: a statement in which important news is given
word.entryExample: The announcement said the train would be late.

word.entryDescription: slightly angry
word.entryExample: His constant questions about my age made me annoyed.

word.entryDescription: making someone slightly angry
word.entryExample: William was angry and said that I was really annoying.

word.entryDescription: happening once a year or based on one year
word.entryExample: The annual rainfall is between 2.5 and 4.5 metres.

word.entryDescription: fear of being fat that makes people stop eating which results in a dangerous weight loss
word.entryExample: Anorexia and bulimia are quite common eating disorders.

word.entryDescription: one more
word.entryExample: Would you like another piece of cake?

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'answer' – to reply to
word.entryExample: Kim answered the teacher's question.

word.entryDescription: a cold icy continent at the very southern end of the earth
word.entryExample: Antarctica is too cold to have rain.

word.entryDescription: not showing consideration for other people or society in general
word.entryExample: Arson could be seen as really anti-social – it has a negative effect on society.

word.entryDescription: the state of being worried that something bad is going to happen
word.entryExample: Relaxation can help you manage stress and anxiety.

word.entryDescription: feeling nervous and worried
word.entryExample: It's time to go home – your mother will be anxious.

word.entryDescription: used with 'not' to say that something used to be or happen but it has now stopped
word.entryExample: My dad got up to have a look, but he didn't see anything. After that I couldn't sleep anymore!

word.entryDescription: anybody; any person
word.entryExample: Is anyone going to dance? It's a party!

word.entryDescription: used to refer to any one thing when it is not important to say exactly what
word.entryExample: Is there anything to eat?

word.entryDescription: besides this; with the exception of this
word.entryExample: We're skiing. Is there anything else you can do in the mountains apart from this?
